description:
Algoriphagus jejuensis is a species of bacteria that was first isolated from soil samples collected in Jeju Island, South Korea. It belongs to the genus Algoriphagus, which is a member of the phylum Bacteroidetes.

Algoriphagus jejuensis is a Gram-negative, non-spore-forming, and aerobic bacterium. It is characterized by its rod-shaped cells and the ability to form orange-pigmented colonies due to the presence of carotenoid pigments. The optimal growth temperature for this species is around 30Â°C, and it can tolerate a wide range of pH values, ranging from 6.0 to 9.0.

Taxonomically, Algoriphagus jejuensis is closely related to other Algoriphagus species, sharing similarities in their 16S rRNA gene sequences and phenotypic characteristics. It is capable of hydrolyzing various macromolecules, such as starch, casein, and Tween 80, indicating its ability to utilize a diverse range of organic compounds as carbon and energy sources.

The isolation and characterization of Algoriphagus jejuensis contribute to our understanding of the microbial diversity and ecological roles of bacteria in soil environments, particularly in the Jeju Island region of South Korea.
